div.div: COVID-19: Hunger & Food Resources for Households

div.p: How to access food assistance during the COVID-19 crisis.

strong.em: Para leer esto en Español, apriete aquí.

p.span: Information and links to food assistance programs in Massachusetts can be found below. Please note that this is not a comprehensive list of all available programs and that information is subject to change as information is continuously changing.

em.span: Click a resource below to jump directly to that section

span.a: Pandemic EBT - related to school meals

strong.a: Get Help - Project Bread's FoodSource Hotline

hr.h4: SNAP, the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, is a federal nutrition program that provides eligible recipients with a monthly cash benefit to purchase groceries.

li.span: SNAP benefits can be used to purchase food at grocery stores, convenience stores, and some farmers' markets and co-op food programs.
SNAP benefits are given to you each month on a plastic card called an EBT (electronic benefits tansfer) card, which works like a debit card.
SNAP is a nutrition program. It is not a welfare cash assistance program (which is called TAFDC).
SNAP is a federal entitlement program. That means anyone who is eligible will receive benefits. You will not be taking away benefits from someone else if you apply.

p.span: If you have lost your job or work hours because of COVID-19, you can apply for SNAP at any time. You do not have to wait to file an application. Changes to SNAP during the crisis include:

li.span: Everyone eligible will receive the maximum household benefit
All applications will be treated as urgent. Applicants will only be interviewed if absolutely necessary to approve their application.

em.span: More information for workers who lost hours or jobs due to COVID-19: English | Español

strong.span: Apply for SNAP benefits today by visiting DTA Connect.

li.span: New SNAP recipients will receive their EBT card by mail only and it may take 5-10 days to receive your card. People experiencing homelessness can use a shelter address to receive their card.
For assistance with SNAP, questions about your eligibility, or applying for benefits, call Project Bread's FoodSource Hotline.

h4.span: Project Bread is working with the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education and many schools and community partners to provide families with access to school meals while schools are closed.

li.span: There are more than 1,300 sites across the state providing free meals.
All kids and teens ages 0-18 are eligible to receive these free meals.
No registration or I.D. is required.
Meals may be picked up by parents and in some cases the meals are delivered to bus stops.
Learn also about Pandemic EBT, which you may be receiving,

p.span: Here is our most up-to-date information on locations providing free school meals.
Please be aware, this information is continuously changing, so keep checking back if you don't find any meals in your community!
for a larger view of the map.
Scroll over the map to zoom, and click the pins for detailed meal site information.

hr.h4: WIC is a federal nutrition program that provides healthy foods, nutrition education, and other services free of charge to Massachusetts families who qualify.

p.span: People who use WIC should plan to arrive at the grocery store early in the morning before items are cleared out for the day. You can call the store and find out what days they are restocking certain items.

li.span: Contact your local WIC Office with any questions about breastfeeding, nutrition, or shopping.

p.span: All WIC Programs are providing all services—including applying for benefits—by phone: 1-800-942-1007. Hours are Monday-Friday 9am-5pm.

li.span: If you hear a recording, leave a message with your name and telephone number

span.a: Click here for more information and updates.

hr.h4: P-EBT provides households an EBT card with the value of free school breakfast and lunch reimbursement rates for the days that schools are closed to help them purchase groceries.

p.span: P-EBT is a crisis response program created by the Families First Coronavirus Response Act.

All Massachusetts students (Pre-K - 12 grade) who are enrolled in or eligible for free or reduced-price school meals or attend a school that offers universal free school breakfast and lunch will receive the P-EBT benefit at the end of April/early May. If you are a household that receives monthly SNAP benefits, you will receive your P-EBT benefits on your current EBT card.
Like a debit card, the P-EBT card can be used to purchase food at grocery stores.
Using the benefit will not impact a family's or child's immigration status.

div.span: If you are a household that is eligible to receive SNAP benefits, Project Bread strongly encourages you to enroll in SNAP as soon as possible to expedite receiving P-EBT. If you have questions or need assistance, please call Project Bread's FoodSource Hotline.

hr.h4: Meals on Wheels is a program that offers well-balanced meals to adults through home delivery or congregated dining sites.

p.span: Meals on Wheels is run by senior nutrition agencies located throughout Massachusetts.
Call 1-800-243-4636 to find the closest agency.
If you need home-delivered meals, staff will make an appointment for a home-delivered meal assessment.

hr.h4: Food pantries provide free emergency groceries to individuals and families in their local communities.

p.span: For the latest information about pantry hours and operations, please visit:

li.span: The Food Bank of Western Massachusetts: www.foodbankwma.org

em.span: If you are seeking support from food pantries at this time, and are not currently enrolled in SNAP, Project Bread strongly encourages you to learn if you are eligible for SNAP benefits and to apply. This will provide you with consistent, monthly cash assistance to purchase your own groceries.

hr.h4: Project Bread's toll-free FoodSource Hotline is the only comprehensive information and referral service in Massachusetts for anyone facing hunger or needing food assistance.

p.span: If you or someone you know living in Massachusetts needs food assistance, please refer them to Project Bread's FoodSource Hotline, toll-free and confidential, at 1-800-645-8333. Monday-Friday: 8am-7pm. Saturday: 10am-2pm.
Our counselors can assist callers with:
Information, eligibility, and over-the-phone application assistance with SNAP
School meal site information
Summer meal site information
Local community resources, such as food pantries and meal services

Our counselors can assist callers in 160 languages and their is a dedicated line to assist our hearing-impaired community at TTY: 1-800-377-1292. More information can be found, here. This service is available to all Massachusetts residents.

h4.a: Our Policy Proposals for Combating Hunger Through COVID-19 & Beyond

div.p: At Project Bread, we know that food insecurity is not caused by scarcity of food, but by systemic barriers that result in unequal access to basic necessities. We need widespread policy solutions to break down barriers through the duration of this crisis and beyond.

h4.a: COVID-19 Response Updates: Where We Stand

div.p: We continue to be focused on our programmatic response to COVID-19 in a rapidly changing landscape. Keep checking back for more updates, but as of today, here is where we stand.

p.span: PROJECT BREAD
